brief_description: A systematic study of human immune function with the goal of identifying defective mechanisms of immune response in patients treated with TNF-alpha blockade (anti-TNF)
brief_title: Immune response evaluation in patients treated with TNF-alpha blockade (anti-TNF)
condition_studied: Immune response of rheumatiod arthitis and psoriatic arthrits patients to influenza vaccine
description: This project is to develop and apply the University of Rochester Program for Biodefense of Immunocompromised Populations (URPBIP) to the systematic study of human immune function with the goal of identifying defective mechanisms of immune response in patients treated with TNF-alpha blockade (anti-TNF).  Studies are designed to detect changes that are likely to be induced by sustained TNF-alpha neutralization in the immune homeostasis and immune responsiveness of B-cells, T-cells and Dendritic cells.  Although the study is not specifically designed to understand immune function in the elderly, the inclusion of a subset of patients and controls over and under 50 may result in the discovery of age-specific defects.
endpoints:
1. Using flow cytometry, define immature, transitional, pre-GC, and marginal zone (CD1c) B-cells
  2. Using flow cytometry, assess the activation status, migration potential, and the presence of survival signal receptors on naive and memory B cells subsets
  3. Using flow cytometry, identify the effects of anti-TNF on monocyte function and maturation
hypothesis: We postulate that given the pleiotropic activities of TNFalpha, the immune function of patients on chronic TNFalpha blockade will be altered by the combination of two critical factors: the quantitative and qualitative changes on steady state immune homeostasis; and the quantitative and qualitative changes in the way that a TNFalpha-deprived immune system responds to mitogenic and antigen-specific stimulation.
objectives:
1. To study the impact of anti-TNF in B-cell homeostasis by analyzing the steady state B-cell populations in anti-TNF patients and controls
  2. To determine the impact of anti-TNF in B-cell responsiveness in vitro
  3. Determine if anti-TNF agents increase the risk of infection in patients with inflammatory arthritis by inhibiting the maturation of monocytes into immature and mature myeloid DC
  4. Determine if anti-TNF agents increase the risk of infection in patients with inflammatory arthritis by altering the function of both mature and immature myeloid DC subsets
